objectives.title: Networking Concepts
objectives.description: Explain basic networking concepts including the OSI model, network topologies, and protocols

objectives.title: Infrastructure
objectives.description: Determine and explain the appropriate cabling, device and storage technologies

objectives.title: Network Operations
objectives.description: Use best practices to manage the network, determine policies and ensure business continuity

objectives.title: Network Security
objectives.description: Summarize physical security and common attacks while securing the wired and wireless network

objectives.title: Network Troubleshooting and Tools
objectives.description: Explain the troubleshooting methodology and the appropriate tools to support connectivity and performance

questions.questionText: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for establishing, maintaining, and terminating sessions between applications?
questions.explanation: The Session Layer (Layer 5) of the OSI model is responsible for establishing, maintaining, and terminating sessions between applications. It manages dialogue control and synchronization between communicating systems.

questions.questionText: What is the default subnet mask for a Class B IP address?
questions.explanation: Class B IP addresses use a default subnet mask of 255.255.0.0, which provides 16 bits for the network portion and 16 bits for the host portion of the address.

questions.questionText: Which port number is used by HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure) uses port 443 by default. This is the secure version of HTTP, which uses port 80.

questions.questionText: What is the maximum cable length for Cat 6 Ethernet cable when running at 1 Gbps?
questions.explanation: Category 6 (Cat 6) Ethernet cable supports speeds up to 1 Gbps at a maximum distance of 100 meters (328 feet). This is the standard maximum length for most Ethernet copper cabling.

questions.questionText: Which type of fiber optic cable is typically used for long-distance transmissions?
questions.explanation: Single-mode fiber optic cable is used for long-distance transmissions because it has a smaller core diameter (8-10 microns) that allows light to travel in a single path, reducing signal dispersion and enabling transmission over greater distances.

questions.questionText: Which RAID level provides disk mirroring without parity or striping?
questions.explanation: RAID 1 provides disk mirroring, where data is written identically to two or more drives. It offers redundancy without parity or striping, providing fault tolerance but no performance improvement.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a VLAN?
questions.explanation: A VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network) is used to logically segment a network, creating separate broadcast domains within a physical network infrastructure. This improves security, performance, and management.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices on a network?
questions.explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses and other network configuration parameters to devices on a network, eliminating the need for manual configuration.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of implementing QoS on a network?
questions.explanation: Quality of Service (QoS) is implemented to prioritize network traffic, ensuring that critical applications and services receive the necessary bandwidth and low latency they require for optimal performance.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack involves flooding a network with traffic to make it unavailable?
questions.explanation: A DDoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack involves flooding a network or server with traffic from multiple sources to overwhelm it and make it unavailable to legitimate users.

questions.questionText: Which wireless security protocol provides the strongest encryption?
questions.explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) is the newest and most secure wireless security protocol, providing stronger encryption and better protection against brute-force attacks compared to its predecessors.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of a DMZ in network security?
options: To create a buffer zone between internal and external networks
questions.explanation: A DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) creates a buffer zone between an internal network and the internet, where public-facing servers can be placed with limited access to the internal network, enhancing security.

questions.questionText: Which command is used to test connectivity between two hosts?
questions.explanation: The ping command is used to test connectivity between two hosts by sending ICMP echo request packets and waiting for echo reply packets, measuring response time and packet loss.

questions.questionText: What is the first step in the network troubleshooting methodology?
options: Establish a theory of probable cause
questions.explanation: The first step in the network troubleshooting methodology is to identify the problem by gathering information, questioning users, and determining what has changed.

questions.questionText: Which tool would you use to identify the path packets take between source and destination?
questions.explanation: Traceroute (tracert on Windows) is used to identify the path packets take between source and destination by showing each hop along the route and the time taken for each hop.

questions.questionText: What does the acronym DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS stands for Domain Name System, which translates human-readable domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to identify each other on the network.

questions.questionText: Which IPv4 address range is reserved for private networks?
questions.explanation: The 10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255 range is one of three IPv4 address ranges reserved for private networks (along with 172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255 and 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255).

questions.questionText: What is the maximum transmission speed of 802.11ac Wi-Fi?
questions.explanation: 802.11ac (Wi-Fi 5) can achieve maximum theoretical speeds of up to 1.3 Gbps on the 5 GHz band, though actual speeds depend on various factors including channel width and MIMO configuration.

questions.questionText: Which backup type backs up only the files that have changed since the last full backup?
questions.explanation: A differential backup backs up all files that have changed since the last full backup, regardless of any other backups performed in between. This differs from incremental backups which only backup changes since the last backup of any type.

questions.questionText: What type of authentication uses something you have and something you know?
questions.explanation: Two-factor authentication (2FA) combines two different authentication factors, such as something you know (password) and something you have (smartphone, token), providing stronger security than single-factor authentication.

questions.questionText: Which cable tester function verifies that wires are connected to the correct pins?
questions.explanation: Wire mapping is a cable tester function that verifies each wire is connected to the correct pin at both ends of the cable, detecting crossed pairs, reversed pairs, and other wiring faults.

questions.questionText: Which protocol operates at Layer 2 of the OSI model and prevents switching loops?
questions.explanation: STP (Spanning Tree Protocol) operates at Layer 2 (Data Link Layer) of the OSI model and prevents switching loops by creating a loop-free logical topology in networks with redundant paths.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of NAT (Network Address Translation)?
options: To translate private IP addresses to public IP addresses
questions.explanation: NAT (Network Address Translation) translates private IP addresses used on internal networks to public IP addresses for internet communication, allowing multiple devices to share a single public IP address.

questions.questionText: Which type of DNS record maps a domain name to an IPv6 address?
questions.explanation: An AAAA record (quad-A record) maps a domain name to an IPv6 address, while an A record maps to an IPv4 address. The four A's represent the four times larger address space of IPv6.

questions.questionText: What is the administrative distance of OSPF?
questions.explanation: OSPF (Open Shortest Path First) has an administrative distance of 110. Administrative distance is used by routers to select the best path when multiple routing protocols provide route information for the same destination.
